definition: Dermal accumulation of hemosiderin pigment, often secondary to stasis, hemorrhage, or inflammation.
clinical: Pigmented lesions, often on the lower legs (stasis).
pathogenesis: Breakdown of red blood cells leading to iron accumulation in macrophages (siderophages).
microscopic: Coarse, refractive yellow-brown granules in the dermis, typically within siderophages or extracellular.
ancillary_studies: Perls (Prussian Blue) stain: Positive (granular blue staining). Fontana-Masson: Negative.
differential_diagnosis: Melanin pigmentation (Fontana-Masson positive), Tattoo pigment, Drug-induced pigmentation.
prognosis_and_prediction: Benign; persistence depends on underlying cause.

related_figures.legend: Perls stain showing numerous cells in the dermis picking up the blue granular stain (siderophages). (Time: 130s)
Perls stain highlighting hemosiderin blue, distinguishing it from melanin. (Time: 244s)

definition: Accumulation of melanin pigment within keratinocytes or melanophages.
clinical: Tan to black stuck-on papules or plaques.
pathogenesis: Benign proliferation of keratinocytes with increased melanin transfer.
microscopic: Acanthosis, papillomatosis, horn cysts, and hyperpigmentation of basal keratinocytes.
ancillary_studies: Fontana-Masson: Positive (Black). Schmorl stain: Positive (Green). Perls stain: Negative.
differential_diagnosis: Hemosiderin (Perls+), Drug-induced pigmentation (may be Fontana+ and Perls+).

related_figures.legend: Fontana-Masson stain turning melanin pigment black within the lesion. (Time: 310s)

definition: Degenerative changes in dermal elastic tissue induced by chronic ultraviolet radiation exposure.
pathogenesis: UV-induced upregulation of elastases and degradation of elastic fibers.
microscopic: Accumulation of basophilic, amorphous, or thickened elastic fibers in the upper dermis. Normal elastic fibers are distinct bundles; solar elastosis appears jumbled.
ancillary_studies: Verhoeff-Van Gieson (VVG/EVG): Stains elastic fibers black/gray. Highlights the jumbled accumulation in solar elastosis vs. fine oxytalan fibers in normal papillary dermis.
differential_diagnosis: Normal skin (orderly elastic fibers), Pseudoxanthoma Elasticum (calcified elastic fibers).

related_figures.legend: Elastic tissue stain showing normal large black elastin bundles in the reticular dermis. (Time: 435s)
Elastic tissue stain showing breakdown and jumbled accumulation of elastin fibers characteristic of solar elastosis. (Time: 546s)

definition: Abnormal accumulation of mucin (glycosaminoglycans) in the dermis.
clinical: Dependent on subtype (e.g., papules, plaques, diffuse induration).
pathogenesis: Overproduction of hyaluronic acid by fibroblasts.
microscopic: Amorphous, basophilic (pale blue) material in the dermis separating collagen bundles.
ancillary_studies: Colloidal Iron: Positive (Blue). Alcian Blue: Positive (Blue). PAS: Negative (usually).

related_figures.legend: Colloidal iron stain showing abundant blue mucin material. (Time: 678s)

definition: Infection of the skin by fungal organisms (dermatophytes, yeast, or molds).
pathogenesis: Invasion of stratum corneum or dermis by fungal elements.
microscopic: Hyphae, pseudohyphae, or spores within the stratum corneum or dermis.
ancillary_studies: PAS (Periodic Acid-Schiff): Stains fungal cell walls red/pink. PAS-D (PAS with Diastase): Digests glycogen (removing background red) but leaves fungus and basement membrane red. GMS (Grocott Methenamine Silver): Stains fungus black.
differential_diagnosis: Clear cell acanthoma (PAS+ glycogen removed by diastase), Paget disease.

related_figures.legend: PAS stain highlighting the basement membrane and structures in red. (Time: 760s)
PAS with Diastase (PAS-D) showing removal of glycogen, highlighting resistant structures (fungus, BMZ). (Time: 802s)

definition: Infection by Mycobacterium species (M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, or atypical mycobacteria).
microscopic: Granulomas (caseating or non-caseating). Organisms are slender red rods.
ancillary_studies: Fite Stain: Positive (Red/Pink rods/snappers). Preferred over AFB/Kinyoun for M. leprae and atypical mycobacteria due to gentler decolorization.
prognosis_and_prediction: Dependent on species and immune status.

related_figures.legend: Fite stain showing small red bacilli (Mycobacteria) within the tissue. (Time: 1007s)

definition: Skin infection by bacteria, commonly Staphylococcus or Streptococcus.
microscopic: Neutrophilic infiltrate (suppurative). Bacteria appear as small clusters or chains of cocci.
ancillary_studies: Gram Stain: Gram-positive organisms stain blue/purple. Brown-Brenn: Modified Gram stain. Microorganisms are significantly smaller than host cell nuclei.
differential_diagnosis: Fungal infection (yeast are size of nuclei, bacteria are smaller).

related_figures.legend: Gram stain showing clusters (tetrads) of blue/purple Gram-positive cocci. (Time: 1202s)

definition: A form of primary cutaneous amyloidosis characterized by keratin-derived amyloid deposition in the papillary dermis, associated with chronic friction.
clinical: Pruritic, hyperkeratotic papules, often on shins.
pathogenesis: Chronic scratching leads to keratinocyte necrosis; filamentous degeneration of keratin forms amyloid (Keratin-derived).
microscopic: Amorphous eosinophilic globules in the papillary dermis. Acanthosis, hyperkeratosis. May show syringofibroadenomatous hyperplasia in extreme cases.
ancillary_studies: Congo Red: Positive (Green birefringence). Keratin stains (CK5/6, HMWK): Positive. Light chains: Negative.
differential_diagnosis: Lichen simplex chronicus, Macular amyloidosis, Colloid milium.

related_figures.legend: Large collection of amorphous purple substance in the dermis. (Time: 1460s)
Extreme Lichen Amyloidosis showing elongated, intertwining eccrine ducts (syringofibroadenomatosis). (Time: 1704s)

definition: Primary cutaneous amyloidosis characterized by immunoglobulin light chain deposition (AL amyloid).
pathogenesis: Local plasma cell proliferation producing light chains (AL amyloid). Can be associated with systemic amyloidosis (rarely) or injection sites.
microscopic: Large, diffuse masses of amorphous eosinophilic fissured material extending deep into the dermis and subcutis. Numerous plasma cells often present.
ancillary_studies: Congo Red: Positive. Kappa/Lambda: Monotypic restriction common. Keratin stains: Negative.
differential_diagnosis: Lichen amyloidosis (superficial only), Colloid milium, Lipoid proteinosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Low risk of progression to systemic disease, but workup recommended.

related_figures.legend: Deep dermal nodules of amyloid, not limited to the papillary dermis. (Time: 2859s)

definition: Calcific uremic arteriolopathy characterized by vascular calcification and thrombosis leading to ischemia.
clinical: Violaceous, painful, indurated plaques progressing to necrosis/ulceration.
pathogenesis: Calcium deposition in small vessel walls, thrombosis, and ischemia. Often in ESRD.
microscopic: Calcification of small vessel walls (capillaries/arterioles) in the subcutaneous fat. Extravascular calcium in fat lobules. Thrombotic vasculopathy. Epidermal necrosis (late).
ancillary_studies: Von Kossa (Black) or Alizarin Red (Red) for calcium.
differential_diagnosis: Monckeberg medial calcific sclerosis (larger vessels, no thrombosis), Dystrophic calcinosis, Metastatic calcinosis.

related_figures.legend: Purple wispy calcium deposition in the subcutaneous fat. (Time: 1879s)
Calcification of the blood vessel wall within the subcutaneous fat. (Time: 1934s)

definition: Cutaneous reaction to exogenous tattoo pigment.
clinical: Induration, erythema, or nodules within a tattoo.
pathogenesis: Foreign body reaction or hypersensitivity (common with red ink).
microscopic: Exogenous pigment granules (uniform size) in the dermis, intracellular (macrophages) and extracellular. Red ink often elicits lymphoplasmacytic or pseudolymphomatous infiltrates.
ancillary_studies: None usually required. Pigment is refractile but not birefringent like foreign material.
differential_diagnosis: Blue nevus, Melanoma (biologic pigment varies in size/shape).
prognosis_and_prediction: Benign; may require removal or steroid treatment.

related_figures.legend: Fine, granular exogenous pigment in the dermis (Red ink). (Time: 2178s)
Inflammatory reaction (pseudolymphomatous) to red tattoo ink. (Time: 2275s)

definition: A form of primary cutaneous amyloidosis with subtle amyloid deposition in the papillary dermis.
clinical: Hyperpigmented patches, often with a rippled pattern (e.g., interscapular). Associated with Notalgia Paresthetica.
microscopic: Subtle, small eosinophilic globules in the papillary dermis. Melanophages present. Occasional necrotic/dyskeratotic keratinocytes in basal layer.
ancillary_studies: Congo Red: Positive. CK5/6 or HMWK: Positive (keratin origin).

related_figures.legend: Subtle amyloid in papillary dermis with melanophages and occasional dyskeratotic keratinocytes. (Time: 2396s)

clinical: Slate-gray or blue discoloration of sun-exposed skin.
pathogenesis: Ingestion of colloidal silver or local implantation.
microscopic: Tiny, uniform black granules depositing preferentially on elastic fibers and the basement membrane of eccrine glands.
ancillary_studies: Darkfield microscopy: Granules appear bright white ("stars in the sky").
differential_diagnosis: Chrysiasis (Gold - larger granules), Mercury, Ochronosis (larger yellow-brown banana bodies).

related_figures.legend: Fine granules depositing on elastin fibers. (Time: 2576s)
Granules depositing around the basement membrane of eccrine glands (diagnostic feature). (Time: 2641s)

definition: Deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the dermis or subcutis.
clinical: Firm, painful nodules (tophi), often on the ear helix or digits.
microscopic: Pale pink, amorphous material in the dermis composed of feathery/needle-like crystal shadows (dissolved by formalin). Surrounded by palisaded granulomas (histiocytes/giant cells).
ancillary_studies: Alcohol fixation (preserves crystals). Fresh tissue: Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. CD68: Highlights surrounding histiocytes.
differential_diagnosis: Pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate - rhomboid, weakly positive birefringence), Rheumatoid nodule.

related_figures.legend: Pale pink material with a feathery, organized appearance (crystal shadows). (Time: 3094s)
Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia overlying the gouty tophus. (Time: 3382s)
